title: Introduction
content:
* Designed for 'touch' apps - mobile, tablet, desktop
* Only supports WebKit-based browsers (Some support for Firefox, no support for IE)
* Variety of functionality built-in, both for logic (data), and user interface (components)

title: Strengths
content:
* Consuming data from local sources (HTML5 localStorage, JSON file), remote sources (JSONP, AJAX, REST), and custom sources (PhoneGap Contacts API, etc.)
* Dynamic page components constructed entirely in JavaScript
* Extensible and clear architecture
* Well designed, documented, supported and thought out

title: Weaknesses
content:
* Only supporting WebKit makes it unsuitable for a general web application
* Does have commercial licensing, so must establish whether the open license fits within bounds of what you are doing
* Some may not like the idea of representing content without markup

title: Central Components
content:
* Application
* Viewport
* Store
* Model
* Controller
* View

title: Why?
content:
* Cross platform, cross device - nearly all the main quirks are handled for you
* What about jqMobile and jqTouch? 
    * Very similar in a lot of ways
    * Both have the same problem - ST forces content in Javascript, jq-variants force too much behaviour into the markup
 * Easily paired with PhoneGap for cross-device apps

title: Good For
content:
* Mobile and tablet applications
* Prototyping web/mobile/tablet applications
* Very data-centric touch applications

title: Bad For
content:
* Web applications
* Applications with a UI that is unique from standard patterns
* Applications with a lot of content, vs behavior
